systems but if you think about live coding of realtime systems there's sort of two contexts that you imagine that
happening in one is the idea where you're uh live coding the underlying
realtime system so you're sort of using some higher level language to sort of control a realtime system that's running
underneath but there's a second idea that I'm more interested in which is the idea of actually live coding the
realtime system itself so we're actually looking at livecoding the realtime system in real time real time real time
so the realtime systems that I'm particularly interested are these systems that are connected to the
environment in some way to the acoustic space in the context of audio which we're going to be talking about quite a
lot today so this being the acoustic space that we're all sharing and it sort
of highlights this idea of firm realtime systems so if we kind of imagine that on
the one side we have uh hard realtime systems um and actually Martin gave a
great example of a hard realtime system today a sort of a a short range defense
gun for for a ship and you can imagine this hard real time system and it's sort of looking at this missile that's coming
in and it's sitting there and it's going garbage collect shoot down the missile garbage collect shoot down the missile
you know it's it's it's not really a choice is it you've got to shoot down the missile so that if we take that as
being a hard realtime system on the one side then on the other side we kind of have the idea of a soft real time system
and a soft real time system in some senses you know it's a little bit wishy-washy in the sense that that it's sort of like we want to try and hit all
of our deadlines but but if we miss a couple we'll hopefully make up for them a little bit later and we've got a
little bit of flexibility but but Sound and Music aren't really like that either right on
the one hand no one's going to die if I miss a couple of timing events in this musical performance but at the same time
it's going to really affect the quality of the performance it's going to sound bad if we start missing events so we
really don't want to miss any events the other thing is that our uh human oral perception is actually uh very sensitive
so we we hear Rhythm down to sort of about 30 milliseconds or so but then in
fact we we hear tambal changes right down to the sort of millisecond range 1
millisecond so compared to our other sense perceptions which are actually significantly higher than that our

later so as well as talking about programming the world though the other idea that
is maybe perhaps even more important that I'd like you to Hope take home from this talk is the idea of programming in
the world and this is sort of the idea that programming can be about a journey it doesn't have to be always about a
product so very often we get carried away with the idea that programming is always about delivering something some
kind of artifact some product at the end of the process but one of the things
that I'm exploring a lot is this idea that the journey itself is the process so what you see in the performance that

the last sort of three or four years now um it has a couple of features that make it um somewhat interesting one is this
idea of being strongly timed which by which really what we're talking about is that there's a realtime um scheduling
engine built into the language and environment that gives us some um temporal semantics so particularly
things like we try to have some kind of guarantees over the execution start time of code and also on execution deadlines
for example how long a piece of code will run we actually have exception handling to manage that um it's both
distributed and heterogeneous um heterogeneous in particular not just um obviously multiple CPU architectures um
x86 and arm but also for example targeting gpus as well as CPUs um it's
concurrent supports sort of cooperative and preemptive concurrency um this idea of being wide which we've talked about

it's high performance but perhaps more importantly it's designed to be deterministic so that we have reasonably
